title-group.article-title: Tax Evasion, Conspicuous Consumption, and the Income Tax Rate

contrib-group.aff: 1School of Economics, COMAS, Rishon LeZion, Israel

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Gideon Yaniv is a professor of economics at the College of Management Academic Studies (COMAS), Israel. He received his doctorate in economics from the Hebrew University. His research interests include the economics of crime (in particular tax evasion and welfare fraud) and health-compromising behavior.

author-notes.corresp: Gideon Yaniv, School of Economics, COMAS, 7 Yitzhak Rabin Ave., Rishon LeZion 75190, Israel. Email: gidyan@colman.ac.il

abstract.p: Very often tax collectors initiate an audit on the basis of observed spending capacity that does not seem to conform with declared income. This requires the skillful evader to carefully consider his or her expenditures on conspicuous consumption to avoid drawing the attention of the tax collector. The present article develops a simple model of the taxpayer’s joint evasion-consumption decision that is used to reexamine the widely discussed relationship between tax evasion and the income tax rate. Contrary to the literature’s counterintuitive result, the article shows that an increase in the income tax rate will unambiguously increase the taxpayer’s level of evasion. Furthermore, given that taxpayers vary in their level of true income, a tax rate increase will increase the number of tax evaders as well, consequently increasing the total amount of taxes escaping the tax collector. A related model of boasting about tax evasion is shown to yield some similar results.

body.p: Very often tax collectors initiate an audit on the basis of observed spending capacity (e.g., a fancy sports car, a luxurious vacation rental) that does not seem to conform with the level of declared income. Such audits are based on the premise that one who appears to be living well must have a good income; hence, the purchase of a luxurious asset, if not explained by the income declared, has been the consequence of tax evasion. This requires the skillful evader to carefully consider his or her expenditures on conspicuous consumption to avoid drawing the attention of the tax collector. Surprisingly, while a vast economic literature has separately developed on both tax evasion and conspicuous consumption, there has not been any attempt to connect between the two types of behavior. 1 A first step in this direction is a model by Macho-Stadler and Perez-Castrillo (2002), where the tax collector receives not only the taxpayer’s declaration of income but also some signal that may be correlated with his or her true income. However, the taxpayer in this model cannot control the signal.

The present article develops a simple model of the taxpayer’s joint decision to evade taxes and consume conspicuously that is used to reexamine an important issue in the tax evasion literature: the relationship between tax evasion and the income tax rate. In their seminal paper on income tax evasion, Allingham and Sandmo (1972; hereafter A-S) concluded that the effect of an increase in the income tax rate on declared income is ambiguous, since the negative substitution effect of a tax rate increase is opposed, given decreasing absolute risk aversion, by a positive income effect. In a note on their paper, Yitzhaki (1974) showed that if the penalty for tax evasion is imposed on the evaded tax (as is practically the case) rather than on the undeclared income (as assumed by A-S), an increase in the income tax rate would unambiguously increase declared income because the substitution effect is eliminated. While Yitzhaki’s slight modification of the A-S model generates a clear-cut result, it is, quite oddly, of a counterintuitive nature. So is also the case with the entry condition into tax evasion: intuitively, one would expect the incentive to evade taxes to increase with the income tax rate; however, under Yitzhaki’s penalty function, the incentive to evade is independent of the income tax rate. 2 Over the years that followed, most theoretical contributions to the tax evasion literature have adopted Yitzhaki’s formulation of the penalty function, although often expressing disappointment with the failure of the theoretical framework to predict that declared income is negatively related to the income tax rate, a result that accords more with common sense and intuition, as well with empirical findings (e.g., Clotfelter 1983; Crane and Nourzad 1987; Poterba 1987; Alm, Bahl, and Murray 1991; Joulfaian and Rider 1996). 3

Because Yitzhaki’s unambiguous result emerges due to the elimination of the intuitive substitution effect, thereby sustaining a counterintuitive income effect, one may attempt to modify A-S model in a way that would rather eliminate the latter and sustain the former. A possible starting point is the assumption of risk neutrality, under which the income effect is zero. While the early theoretical literature on tax evasion is based on the assumption of risk aversion and the use of Von-Neumann-Morgenstern expected utility functions, the empirical evidence on risk preferences is rather mixed (e.g., Machina 1987; Camerer 1995). Furthermore, for the situation of tax reporting, where honestly paying taxes constitutes a certain loss that tax evasion aims to avoid, Kahneman and Tversky’s (1979) prospect theory implies that taxpayers behave as risk lovers. Risk neutrality may thus be viewed as a compromise between the alternative assumptions. In fact, for the case of losses and high stakes, experimental evidence shows that people are approximately risk neutral (Kachelmeier and Shehata 1992). In any case, the assumption of risk neutrality is not alien to the tax evasion literature: models that focus on audit design (e.g., Reinganum and Wilde 1985; Macho-Stadler and Perez-Castrillo 2002) or optimal taxation with tax evasion (e.g., Cremer and Gahvari 1994) often use risk neutrality to keep the analysis tractable.

However, applying risk neutrality to A-S model yields a corner solution, at which the taxpayer declares his or her true income or no income at all, irrespective of the income tax rate. Allowing the probability of audit to depend on declared income may provide the concavity required for an interior solution; yet, the optimal level of declaration would remain independent of the income tax rate. Recognizing, however, that audits may be triggered by observed spending capacity, the present article allows the probability of audit to depend not only on declared income but on conspicuous consumption as well. This turns out to generate the desired relationship between declared income and the income tax rate.

Connecting between the probability of audit and conspicuous consumption introduces a new player to the determination of the amount evaded as well as to the mere decision of whether or not to evade: the taxpayer’s preference for conspicuous consumption. As may be expected, the greater the taxpayer’s conspicuity preference, the less likely he or she is to evade taxes, and, if opting for dishonesty, the less tax he or she will evade. Furthermore, contrary to Yitzhaki’s, the entry condition into tax evasion becomes dependent on the income tax rate and the taxpayer’s true income. An increase in the income tax rate is shown to increase not just the taxpayer’s level of evasion but the number of tax evaders as well, consequently increasing the total amount of taxes escaping the tax collector. Finally, rather than risk detection through spending on conspicuous consumption, taxpayers sometime risk detection through publicly boasting about not paying all their taxes. The article concludes with introducing a model of tax evasion with boasting that yields some similar results.

sec.title: The Evasion-Consumption Decision
sec.p:
Consider a taxpayer with a fixed income, I, which is subject to a proportional income tax rate, θ. Suppose that the taxpayer derives utility, U, from spending his or her income on the consumption of conspicuous goods, S, and nonconspicuous goods, N. While the consumption of conspicuous goods is observed by outsiders, including the tax collector, the consumption of nonconspicuous goods is not. Suppose further that the taxpayer may opt to evade taxes by declaring to the tax collector a lower income, X (≤ I). The budget constraint faced by the taxpayer is thus 1
N + S + θ X = I .

The taxpayer’s utility function is assumed to be linear in both types of consumption: 2
U = N + α S ,
where a (>1) represents his or her preference for conspicuous consumption (henceforth, conspicuity coefficient). Hence, a dollar spent on S yields a greater utility than a dollar spent on N.

At the beginning of the period, the taxpayer transfers the amount θX to the tax collector and uses his or her net income, I − θX, to purchase the conspicuous and nonconspicuous goods. During the period, he or she might be audited by the tax collector. The probability of audit, P, is assumed to increase with the value of the conspicuous goods and to decrease with the amount of income declared. That is, 3
P = P ( S , X ) ,
where PS > 0, PX < 0, PSS > 0, PXX > 0, and PSX = PXS < 0. The latter assumption asserts that the greater the level of declaration, the smaller the increase in the probability of audit due to spending an additional dollar on conspicuous consumption.

If the taxpayer is audited, his or her underdeclaration will be revealed and a penalty, F, which is a multiple λ (>1) of the evaded tax, θ(I-X), will be imposed. Hence, 4

sec.title: Aggregate Tax Evasion
sec.p: Proposition 3 asserts that if the taxpayer is already evading taxes, he or she will evade more in response to an increase in the income tax rate. Proposition 2 implies that if the taxpayer is not evading taxes, he or she might (though not necessarily) enter into tax evasion following an increase in the income tax rate. If all taxpayers were identical in income and tastes, it is possible that no one would opt to evade taxes and no one would find it worthwhile to evade even if the income tax rate increases. 6 However, given that taxpayers vary in their level of true income, consider now the effect of an increase in the income tax rate on the number of tax evaders.

sec.title: Boasting about Tax Evasion
sec.p: Conspicuous consumption aims at impressing others with one’s spending capacity. In doing so, a tax evader might end up impressing the tax collector as well. A related way of impressing others, highlighting one’s financial wit and sophistication, is boasting about cheating the tax collector. It may seem odd that tax evaders would boast about their evasion, but surfing the Internet reveals an amazing number of incidents where tax evaders have been caught because they publicly boasted (e.g., on television, newspapers, and social networks) about not paying all their taxes. 7

A simple model of optimal boasting may yield similar results. Consider a taxpayer who derives utility from net income and boasting about tax evasion. Suppose that boasting, B, is a continuous variable measured on a scale between 0 and 1. Suppose further that a taxpayer may boast even if he or she does not evade taxes (after all, nobody knows what he or she has actually done); hence, the tax collector may not necessarily act in response to boasting. Still, the probability of audit is likely to increase with the intensity of boasting (and decrease with the amount of income declared); hence, P = P(B, X), where PB > 0, PX < 0, PBB > 0, PXX > 0, and PBX = PXB < 0.

When the taxpayer declares truthfully, X = I, and F = 0. Equation (20) thus reduces to EUB = β > 0, implying that the taxpayer is free to boast as much as he or she pleases (B = 1), as there is no cost involved. Substituting into equation (21), we obtain EUX = – θ + P(1, I)λθ. Evasion is worth the taxpayer’s while if EUX < 0, or if P(1, I)λ < 1. The latter constitutes the entry condition into tax evasion, which is independent of the taxpayer's boasting preference.

Totally differentiating equations (20) and (21) with respect to X, S, θ, β, and ∊, it can be shown as before that if the taxpayer evades some taxes, an increase in the income tax rate will unambiguously increase his or her level of tax evasion and reduce his or her boasting intensity, and that the stronger his or her boasting preference or the greater the exogenous component of the audit probability, the less he or she will evade and the more he or she will boast about evading. However, because the entry condition into tax evasion is independent of the income tax rate, a tax rate increase will not affect the number of evaders as before. Nevertheless, an increase in the income tax rate will increase the total amount of taxes escaping the tax collector.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Assuming that net income is spent on conspicuous and nonconspicuous consumption and that the taxpayer has preference for the former but is concerned with the signal it transmits to the tax collector, the article derives four major results. First, the entry condition into tax evasion is stricter than Yitzhaki’s well-known condition, involving both the taxpayer’s preference for conspicuous consumption and the income tax rate. Specifically, the stronger the taxpayer’s conspicuity preference, the less likely he or she is to evade taxes, but the higher the income tax rate, the more likely he or she is to evade. Second, contrary to Yitzhaki’s widely applied but counterintuitive result, an increase in the income tax rate will unambiguously increase the taxpayer’s level of evasion. Rather than reducing evasion, it will reduce his or her spending on conspicuous consumption. Third, the stronger the taxpayer’s preference for conspicuous consumption, the less he or she will evade and the more he or she will consume conspicuously. Fourth, given that taxpayers vary in their level of true income, an increase in the income tax rate will increase not just each taxpayer’s level of evasion but the number of tax evaders as well, consequently increasing the total amount of taxes escaping the tax collector. Allowing the taxpayer to boast about his or her tax evasion, rather than consume conspicuously, yields some similar results.

For surveys of the tax evasion literature, see Pyle (1989), Cowell (1990), Andreoni, Erard, and Feinstein (1998), and Slemrod and Yitzhaki (2002). Recent contributions to the conspicuous consumption literature include Friedman and Ostrov (2008), Arrow and Dasgupta (2009), Mandel (2009), and Charles, Hurst, and Roussanov (2009).

The reason for this is that as long as the taxpayer declares truthfully, an increase in the income tax rate does not generate any income effect. Since the substitution effect is also eliminated, irrespective of the level of declaration, the incentive to evade is nonresponsive to the income tax rate.

Surprisingly, extensions of Yitzhaki’s framework to include some more realistic features of the evasion decision, have sometimes led to the desired prediction under some restriction on the new feature. Gordon (1989) showed that if taxpayers differ by an honesty characteristic, the more honest of them will respond to a tax rate increase in the intuitively expected way. Yaniv (1999) used prospect theory to show that in the presence of obligatory advance tax payments, with the reference point being income after the payment of the tax advance and prior to the filing of a return, a tax rate increase will decrease compliance if compliance is sufficiently high. Lee (2001) showed that if tax evaders can self-insure against the possible penalty, an increase in the tax rate will lead to less tax compliance, providing that the marginal productivity of self-insurance is not too small. Lin and Yang (2001) showed that extending Yitzhaki’s model from static to a dynamic setting reverses the counterintuitive prediction of the static model. Dhami and al-Nowaihi (2007) showed that under cumulative prospect theory, with the legal after-tax income being the reference point, tax evasion is strictly increasing in the tax rate providing that an evader also suffers some (proportional to the evaded income) stigma if being caught.

The probability of audit may be viewed as representing the fraction of the period left after the possible occurrence of an audit, during which the lower level of conspicuous goods is consumed. That is, the taxpayer expects to consume S during a fraction 1 − P of the period and S − F during a fraction P of the period, the expected consumption during the period being S − PF.

Notice also that if all taxpayers had an identical income, which is likely to be known to the tax collector, underdeclaration would immediately reveal itself without an audit and conspicuous consumption would lose any informative value.

For example, in May 2005, Lee Mroszak, a disc jockey known as “Crazy Cabbie,” was sentenced to a year in prison for tax evasion after boasting about it on the Howard Stern Show (http://www. encyclopedia.com/doc/1P1-108730422.html). In February 2010, Marla and Phyllis Stevens were indicted by a federal grand jury on five charges of income tax evasion after Marla boasted on her blog about how she and her spouse violated federal tax laws (http://m.desmoinesregister.com/BETTER/news.jsp?key=607991). Also, in the 2000, businessmen were quoted on the front page of the New York Times boasting about how they neither paid taxes nor withheld them from their employees’ paychecks (Johnston, 2005, 45).
